ndt.description: The Network Diagnostic Tool (NDT) provides a sophisticated measurement of a connection's capacity for 'bulk transport'. It evaluates how well a connection performs when trying to move large amounts of data.

key_metrics.Download Speed: The rate at which data is transferred from the server to the client. Measured in bps/Mbps.
key_metrics.Upload Speed: The rate at which data is transferred from the client to the server.
key_metrics.RTT (Round-Trip Time): The time it takes for a packet to travel from the source to the destination and back. High RTT indicates latency issues.
key_metrics.TCP Congestion Control: NDT reveals how different algorithms (Cubic, BBR, Reno) handle network bottlenecks. This is crucial for understanding why speeds might be capped even if bandwidth is high.
key_metrics.Bulk Transport Capacity: An estimate of the throughput the connection can sustain over a longer period.

traceroute.description: Traceroute maps the path packets take through the internet. M-Lab uses 'scamper' to perform these tests from the server back to the client.

key_metrics.Hops: The sequence of routers (intermediaries) between the server and the client.
key_metrics.Hop RTT: The round-trip time to each specific intermediary router. Significant jumps between two hops indicate where the congestion or delay is occurring.
key_metrics.Path Information: Identifies the specific IP addresses and network providers (ASNs) through which data travels.
key_metrics.Packet Loss at Hop: Identifies if specific routers are dropping packets, which can indicate hardware failure or severe congestion at a specific exchange point.

general_troubleshooting.high_latency: Look for high RTT in NDT and identify the specific hop where RTT jumps in Traceroute.
general_troubleshooting.low_throughput: Check if TCP Congestion Control is limiting the window size, or if packet loss is causing frequent retransmissions.
general_troubleshooting.intermittent_connection: Compare multiple NDT tests over time to see if performance drops correlate with specific times of day or specific network paths.
